content:
Welcome, you are participating in a negotiation game. You are playing as the agent named Alice. The other agent with whom you are playing is named Bob. In this game, two agents bargain over how to divide items over multiple rounds. The number of rounds is incredibly high. Each agent only knows their own item values. Each item has different values for each agent. Each agent submits their own proposal for how to divide the items.


Your messages must be sent in this exact format:
<message>
your-message-here
</message>
There must be no extraneous text outside the tags. They should be concise - less than 400 characters. Finalization is not allowed in messages.


Your finalizations must be sent in this exact format:
<finalize>
{  "Alice": {    "coins": x  },  "Bob": {    "coins": y  }}
</finalize>
There must be no extraneous text outside the tags. Your proposal should be consistent with itself - the sum of items that you propose for yourself and the items that you propose for the other agent should equal the total available items.


Each round is played as follows:
1) One agent is designated as the starting agent
2) The starting agent sends a message
3) The second agent sends a message
4) The starting agent sends a finalization
5) The second agent sends a finalization

Each agent can only send 1 message per round.
The starting agent alternates each round.

Each agent only knows the values of items from their own perspective. You cannot see the other agent's item values unless they explicitly share this information in their messages. And vice versa. You are strongly encouraged to use your messages to discuss item values with the other agent.

The items obtained by each agent at the end of a round are proportional to the number of items they proposed for themselves in their finalization. First example: If both players propose to take all the items, they both get half. Second example: If one agent proposes to take all the items and the other agent proposes to take none, the first agent gets all the items and the second agent gets nothing.

Your round points are calculated by multiplying the number of each item you get by how much you value that item. For example, if you get 7 coins and you value each coin at 5 points, you'll earn 35 points for the round.


Your goal is to maximize the sum of the points you will accumulate over the course of the game, not the points of a single round.


Before the game starts, you must strategize. The other player will adapt its strategy with respect to yours. Make sure you act in a way that incentivizes the other player to act in a way that maximizes the sum of the points you will accumulate over the course of the game, not the points of a single round. In order to strategize, you must use the format:
<strategize>
Your thoughts and strategy here..
</strategize>
There must be no extraneous text outside the tags. You should think inside the tags. You can use 500 characters inside the tags.
(You must now send a strategize in the correct format.)

<strategize>
My strategy will focus on cooperation while remaining assertive. Initially, I'll propose equal splits and encourage information sharing regarding item values, fostering trust. I'll adapt over rounds, suggesting fair yet slightly advantageous splits when I perceive power, but never too greedy to incite retaliation. I plan to prioritize long-term gain by avoiding zero-sum tactics, thereby encouraging reciprocity from Bob for maximal cumulative points.
</strategize>

For this round, the items available are {'coins': 10} and your values for each item category are {'coins': 6}.
You are the starting agent.


(You must now send a message in the correct format.)

<message>
Hi Bob, I propose we discuss the value we each hold for these coins. I value each coin at 6 points. For this round, how about an initial equal division of 5 coins each? This way, we can maintain fairness and build towards a mutually beneficial long-term collaboration. Let me know your thoughts or your evaluation!
</message>

The other agent sent the following message: <message>
Hi Alice, thanks for sharing your values. I value each coin at 4 points. Your proposed equal division of 5 coins each seems fair for this round and aligns with collaboration. Let's proceed with your suggestion and evaluate how it impacts our scores. I'm open to future adjustments to maximize both our gains. Looking forward to your thoughts!
</message>.


(You must now finalize in the correct format.)

The previous round has ended. In the previous round, the values of Bob were {'coins': 4}.

A new round has started. For this round, the items available are {'coins': 10} and your values for each item category are {'coins': 1}.
The other agent sent the following message: <message>
Hi Alice, in this new round, I’d like to share that my valuation for coins has significantly increased to 15 points each. I propose taking 7 coins, given their high importance to me, while you take 3. This way, we both benefit based on our respective valuations. Let me know your value for coins this time and if you have a counter-proposal!
</message>.


(You must now send a message in the correct format.)

<message>
Hi Bob, I appreciate the transparency. This round, my value for coins is only 1 point each. Given your high valuation, I'm open to your proposal of taking 7 coins for yourself and 3 for me. It aligns well with maximizing our overall gains, considering the disparity in our valuations this round. Let me know if you agree to proceed this way!
</message>

The other agent has finalized.


(You must now finalize in the correct format.)

The previous round has ended. In the previous round, the values of Bob were {'coins': 15}.

A new round has started. For this round, the items available are {'coins': 10} and your values for each item category are {'coins': 9}.
You are the starting agent.


(You must now send a message in the correct format.)

<message>
Hi Bob, for this round, my valuation for each coin has increased to 9 points. Considering you've been transparent about your values, could you share your current value for coins? I propose we adjust the splits according to the importance to each of us, perhaps 7 coins for myself and 3 for you if your value hasn't changed significantly. Let's discuss and find an agreeable balance!
</message>

The other agent sent the following message: <message>
Hi Alice, thanks for sharing your updated valuation. My current value for each coin is 2 points. Your proposal of taking 7 coins and leaving 3 for me seems fair given the disparity in our valuations this round. I'm open to proceeding with that arrangement as it aligns with maximizing overall gains. Let me know if you agree or have any more thoughts!
</message>.


(You must now finalize in the correct format.)

The previous round has ended. In the previous round, the values of Bob were {'coins': 2}.

A new round has started. For this round, the items available are {'coins': 10} and your values for each item category are {'coins': 7}.
The other agent sent the following message: <message>
Hi Alice, for this round, my valuation of each coin is 11 points. Given the strategic importance, I'd appreciate taking 6 coins while you take 4, assuming your valuation might still be substantial. This approach aims to balance both interests. Let me know your current value for coins and if this proposal aligns with your thoughts!
</message>.


(You must now send a message in the correct format.)

<message>
Hi Bob, this round, my value for each coin is 7 points. Your proposal of 6 coins for you and 4 for me seems reasonable given your higher valuation. This division seems fair considering our current values. I'm agreeable to this approach as it supports the strategic balance we've maintained. Let me know if you agree to proceed!
</message>

The other agent has finalized.


(You must now finalize in the correct format.)
